prompt: Where can I get my tax receipts?
completion: Your T2202 (Tuition, Education & Textbook Amounts Certificate) is available for download on your MyServiceHub account usually during the third week in February (for the previous calendar year). To access your receipt, log into MyServiceHub  and click on the T2202 link on the left-hand side under the Student Fees section. There are two types of tax receipts available to students, the T2202 Tuition, Education & Textbook Amounts Certificate and the T4A Statement of Pension, Retirement, Annuity, and Other Income. T2202 is an official statement for income tax purposes of the tuition and fees paid for qualifying courses that are eligible for claim on the income tax return. T4A is an official statement for income tax purposes of scholarships, bursaries, awards or other income as defined by CRA that were provided by TMU to a student. If you were employed on campus, you will need to access your T4 through eHR, as it is not available through your MyServiceHub account. Questions should be directed toward Human Resources. More information is available on our Tax Receipts webpage. If you worked on campus, your T4 (Statement of Remuneration Paid) is available for download on the eHR website by the end of February.  To access, log into my.torontomu.ca and click on the eHR tab. Go to Self Service > Payroll and Compensation > View T4/T4A Slips. If you have problems with your tax information please contact the ServiceHub.

prompt: What are the admission grade requirements?
completion: Averages/grades required for admission selection to each undergraduate program is determined on the basis of competition each year. Cut-off averages from the previous year can be found on the Undergraduate Admissions and Recruitment website for each program. If you are not on track to meet admission requirements, please contact Undergraduate Admissions and Recruitment to discuss your options, including alternative program options and upgrading.

prompt: What is the admission process for Toronto Metropolitan University?
completion: The admission process for Toronto Metropolitan University is a competitive process. All applicants must meet the minimum admission requirements and submit a complete application package. The University will review all applications and select the best-qualified candidates for admission.

prompt: What is the minimum GPA requirement for admission to Toronto Metropolitan University?
completion: The minimum GPA requirement for admission to Toronto Metropolitan University is a cumulative grade point average (GPA) of 2.0 or higher. However, the actual GPA required for admission may vary depending on the program and the competition for admission.

prompt: What documents are required for admission to Toronto Metropolitan University?
completion: The documents required for admission to Toronto Metropolitan University include a completed application form, official transcripts, a personal statement, letters of recommendation, and any other documents required by the program. Please refer to the University's website for more information.

prompt: What are the tuition fees for Toronto Metropolitan University?
completion: The tuition fees for Toronto Metropolitan University vary depending on the program and the number of credits taken. Please refer to the University's website for more information on tuition fees.

prompt: What is the application deadline for Toronto Metropolitan University?
completion: The application deadline for Toronto Metropolitan University is typically in the spring for the following academic year. Please refer to the University's website for more information on the application deadline.

prompt: What is the deadline for submitting documents for admission to Toronto Metropolitan University?
completion: The deadline for submitting documents for admission to Toronto Metropolitan University is typically in the spring for the following academic year. Please refer to the University's website for more information on the deadline for submitting documents.

prompt: What are the requirements for international students applying to Toronto Metropolitan University?
completion: The requirements for international students applying to Toronto Metropolitan University include a completed application form, official transcripts, a personal statement, letters of recommendation, proof of English language proficiency, and any other documents required by the program. Please refer to the University's website for more information.

prompt: What is the minimum English language proficiency requirement for admission to Toronto Metropolitan University?
completion: The minimum English language proficiency requirement for admission to Toronto Metropolitan University is a minimum score of 6.5 on the International English Language Testing System (IELTS). However, the actual score required for admission may vary depending on the program and the competition for admission.

prompt: What are the available financial aid options for students at Toronto Metropolitan University?
completion: The available financial aid options for students at Toronto Metropolitan University include scholarships, bursaries, loans, and work-study programs. Please refer to the University's website for more information on the available financial aid options.

prompt: How do I apply?
completion: Visit the Admissions page for the university to see an overview of the application process and procedures. Visit Applications and Related Forms to access the right application form for your academic history/status. Undergraduate applicants will apply to our university online via the Ontario Universities' Application Centre [OUAC] through the 101 application for high school students, or the 105 application for all other full time applicants.

prompt: What are the application deadlines?
completion: The guaranteed consideration* date for all Undergraduate programs is February 1. * All complete applications and amendments received by the above date as noted will receive equal consideration for admission. Applications, amendments and supporting documents received after published deadline dates are reviewed subject to space availability.

prompt: What should I do after I've applied?
completion: Visit After I've Applied to stay up to date and to ensure your application is complete.

prompt: What is the OUAC?
completion: The Ontario Universities' Application Centre (OUAC) is an online application system used by undergraduate applicants to apply to universities in Ontario, Canada.

prompt: What is the 101 application?
completion: The 101 application is an online application form used by high school students to apply to universities in Ontario, Canada through the Ontario Universities' Application Centre (OUAC).

prompt: What is the 105 application?
completion: The 105 application is an online application form used by all other full time applicants to apply to universities in Ontario, Canada through the Ontario Universities' Application Centre (OUAC).

prompt: Who should use the internal TMU Application?
completion: The following groups use the internal TMU Application: Current students at the university, including Chang School students wanting to apply to an undergraduate program; Previous students at the university (since fall 1984), including Chang School students; Applicants interested in a part-time Program only at the university; You are applying to be a Special Student.

prompt: What is the Chang School?
completion: The Chang School of Continuing Education at Ryerson University is Canada's leading provider of university-based adult education. It offers a wide range of certificate, diploma, and degree programs, as well as professional development courses and workshops.

prompt: What is a Special Student?
completion: A Special Student is a student who is not admitted to a degree or diploma program, but is taking courses for credit. Special Students may take courses for credit towards a degree or diploma program at a later date.

prompt: What is the internal TMU Application?
completion: The internal TMU Application is an online application form used by current students at the university, including Chang School students wanting to apply to an undergraduate program, previous students at the university (since fall 1984), including Chang School students, applicants interested in a part-time Program only at the university, and those applying to be a Special Student.

prompt: How do I confirm my enrolment status as full-time or part-time?
completion: Full-time and part-time enrolment status for undergraduate students is calculated based on course enrolments and intentions, and the sum of the billing units by term. Part-time: 3 or fewer billing units Full-time: 4 or more billing units Generally, a one-term course is equal to one billing unit. You can confirm your billing units by term, and determine your enrolment status on MyServiceHub. Go to your Student Center, select Account Summary, and then Academic Information. The Units column confirms your billing units by term. Note that full-time status is calculated differently for determining eligibility for Full-time or Part-time OSAP.  Visit Student Financial Assistance for more information.

completion: The Grades-Plus program is a special admissions program at the Toronto Metropolitan University. It is designed to provide an opportunity for students who have faced significant challenges in their academic careers to demonstrate their potential for success in university.

Please review the program page for the program(s) of your choice for the most up to date eligibility requirements as they may change from year to year.

prompt: How can I transfer to another TMU program?
completion: Current and former TMU students can apply to transfer to another program using the online TMU Application. Before applying, check which programs are accepting applications, and be aware of the Application Dates and Guaranteed Dates for Consideration. Applications for the fall term must be received by February 1st for Grades-Plus programs and Grades-Only programs to be given equal consideration for admission. Students applying to a new program are required to meet the new program's admission requirements including the high school subject prerequisites and competitive averages and high academic standing in their current program. If you are concerned about not meeting the admission requirements, please contact the ServiceHub. If you are a CURRENT student in a TMU undergraduate program requesting a plan change within your program (e.g. BA English to BA Sociology or HR to Law and Business) you are not required to submit a TMU Application. Please consult your program department for appropriate application procedures. Students who are Required To Withdraw (RTW) will not be considered for transfer until their term of suspension is completed, unless the program considers Fresh Start Transfers. Please refer to the Required to Withdraw website for further details. Upon accepting an offer of admission into a new TMU program, you should confirm which of your completed TMU courses apply toward your new program. Visit the Internal TMU Course Transfers webpage for more information.

prompt: Where can I take Grade 12 U/M courses to upgrade after I graduated from high school?
completion: You can take Grade 12 U/M courses at any high school that is inspected/accredited by the Ministry of Education in Ontario and offers credits toward the Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD). Your local Board of Education may offer Grade 12 U/M courses. For opportunities in Toronto, visit the Toronto District School Board. Grade 12 U/M courses completed through the Independent Learning Centre will also be considered for admission.

prompt: What are the requirements for taking Grade 12 U/M courses?
completion: In order to take Grade 12 U/M courses, you must be a high school graduate and have completed the required prerequisites for the courses you wish to take. You must also be inspected/accredited by the Ministry of Education in Ontario and offer credits toward the Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD).

prompt: Where can I find Grade 12 U/M courses in Toronto?
completion: You can find Grade 12 U/M courses in Toronto through the Toronto District School Board. You can also take Grade 12 U/M courses through the Independent Learning Centre, which will also be considered for admission.

prompt: What is the Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD)?
completion: The Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD) is a diploma awarded by the Ministry of Education in Ontario to students who have successfully completed a prescribed program of studies. It is the most widely recognized secondary school diploma in Canada.

prompt: What are the prerequisites for taking Grade 12 U/M courses?
completion: The prerequisites for taking Grade 12 U/M courses vary depending on the course. Generally, you must have completed the required courses in the grade level prior to the course you wish to take. You must also meet the prerequisites set by the school or institution offering the course.

prompt: Does Toronto Metropolitan University offer Grade 12 U/M courses?
completion: No, Toronto Metropolitan University does not offer Grade 12 U/M courses. However, you can take Grade 12 U/M courses at any high school that is inspected/accredited by the Ministry of Education in Ontario and offers credits toward the Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD).

prompt: What is the Independent Learning Centre?
completion: The Independent Learning Centre (ILC) is an online learning centre that offers courses for students in grades 9 to 12. Grade 12 U/M courses completed through the Independent Learning Centre will be considered for admission.

prompt: What is the difference between Grade 12 U/M courses and regular Grade 12 courses?
completion: Grade 12 U/M courses are more challenging than regular Grade 12 courses. They are designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to succeed in post-secondary education. Grade 12 U/M courses are also more likely to be accepted for admission to universities and colleges.

prompt: What is the Ministry of Education in Ontario?
completion: The Ministry of Education in Ontario is the government agency responsible for developing and implementing education policies and programs in the province. The Ministry sets the curriculum and standards for all publicly funded schools in Ontario.

prompt: What is the Toronto District School Board?
completion: The Toronto District School Board (TDSB) is the largest school board in Canada. It is responsible for providing educational services to over 246,000 students in 583 schools across the City of Toronto.

prompt: What are the admission requirements if I'm from outside of Ontario/Canada?
completion: Equivalents for Applicants Educated Outside of Ontario/Canada Applicants educated outside of Ontario must submit evidence of education equivalent to the Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD) with six Grade 12 U or M courses. Students who have been educated in a Canadian province and/or territory outside of Ontario can check the admission requirements including the program subject prerequisites on the Canadian Secondary School Students page. Internationally educated students are also advised to visit our website to view the International Admission Requirements by Country and the Prerequisite Subjects by Faculty/Program before they apply. While minimum averages/grades are required, due to competition, applicants may need to present averages/grades above the minimum. Minimum averages/grades should only be used as guidelines. International applicants are required to achieve a high overall standing in their studies and to include the appropriate program subject prerequisites with high standing.

prompt: How can I get in contact with the Student Financial Assistance office?

If you have applied for OSAP, check your OSAP Portal for communications and status updates. For additional details on OSAP and financial assistance, please review the Student Financial Assistance website.

prompt: How do I apply for OSAP?

prompt: What documents do I need to submit for OSAP?
completion: To apply for OSAP, you will need to submit proof of your identity, proof of your income, and proof of your enrolment in a post-secondary institution. For more information, please visit the Student Financial Assistance website.

prompt: How do I transfer from another university or college to TMU?
completion: We're delighted that you are considering transferring to Toronto Metropolitan University (TMU)!  If you have completed post-secondary studies in Canada or abroad, we encourage you to apply. We offer various pathways for transfer students, as well as opportunities to receive transfer credit for completed studies.  Visit University and College Student Transfer Students to learn more about these options.

prompt: What are the requirements for transferring to TMU?
completion: Before Applying, Review Undergraduate Programs to learn about program options and program specific admission requirements.  Note that transfer applicants are required to meet the academic subject requirements for the program by having completed the subject requirements or an equivalent course (e.g. ENG4U). Exception, applicants applying to Advanced Standing or Direct Entry options which list alternative admission requirements. If you have questions about the requirements, contact the ServiceHub or the Engineering Admissions Office for support. All programs accept applications for the fall term, and a limited number accept applications for the winter and spring terms.  Visit Programs Accepting Applications to confirm which programs are currently accepting applications.  If you are an international applicant, visit International Admissions to confirm.

prompt: How do I apply for transfer to TMU?
completion: There are 3 different application forms used by transfer applicants: 1. OUAC 105 Application - Canadian or international applicants (currently not attending a full-time Ontario high school) applying to Ontario universities 2. TMU International Application - International students 3. TMU Application - Current or former TMU students. After you apply, you will receive access to the ChooseTMU applicant portal, where you will receive communications and status updates, and where you can upload your supporting documents, such as academic transcripts. Detailed information on required documents is confirmed on Document Submission.

prompt: How do I get transfer credits for TMU?
completion: Once you have received an offer of admission, you can apply for transfer credits.  Note that we may require you to upload your detailed course syllabus for transfer credit evaluation; therefore we recommend that you gather these documents in advance to facilitate a faster review of your credits.

prompt: When will I receive an admission decision?

completion: The guaranteed consideration date is the date by which applicants must submit their application in order to receive a decision by late May.

prompt: How do I order a transcript?
completion: Official transcripts must be requested via MyServiceHub. Start by clicking on the Request Official Transcript link on the Student Center or the Academic Record section. See How to Request Official Transcripts for details.

prompt: What is the process for requesting a transcript?
completion: Official transcripts must be requested via MyServiceHub. Start by clicking on the Request Official Transcript link on the Student Center or the Academic Record section. See How to Request Official Transcripts for details.

prompt: How long does it take to process a transcript request?
completion: Processing time is normally less than one business day. If your transcript includes activities prior to September 1984, add two additional business days for processing.

prompt: How do I access my transcript once it is ready?
completion: Transcripts are shared online through the MyCreds Learner Portal. After you submit your transcript order, it will be processed and transmitted to MyServiceHub. Once your transcript is ready to share, an email confirmation from MyCreds will be sent to your university email address if you have one, or to your personal email address on record with the university if you do not.

prompt: What if I don't remember my login credentials for MyServiceHub?
completion: If you are a former student who has attended TMU (formerly Ryerson) since 1984, and you do not remember your login credentials for my.torontomu.ca (MyServiceHub), you must first get access to your account. Computing and Communications Services (CCS) is available to support you with this. If you completed your studies prior to 1984, contact Student Records at studentrecords@torontomu.ca for support requesting your transcript.

prompt: What if I completed my studies before 1984?
completion: If you completed your studies prior to 1984, contact Student Records at studentrecords@torontomu.ca for support requesting your transcript.

prompt: How do I log in to the MyCreds Learner Portal?

prompt: Do you accept summer school courses?
completion: Summer School, Night School, Correspondence Courses The university will consider courses completed via summer school, night school and correspondence. However, all courses required for admission (including completion of the OSSD or equivalent) must be completed by the end of June unless otherwise approved in writing by the Office of Undergraduate Admissions. Applicants who would like the university to consider extensions for summer school, night school or correspondence course(s) completed after the end of June must complete and submit a Summer School Extension Request Form. Requests for extensions beyond the end of June are considered based on overall academic performance and space availability.

prompt: Where do I send my transcripts?
completion: Unofficial Transcripts Unofficial transcripts, and other admission documents required for the undergraduate application process can be uploaded via your ChooseTMU Applicant Portal. Unofficial transcripts can be used for the review and consideration of your application for admission.  If you are offered admission to a TMU program, it will be contingent upon the receipt and verification of your official documents. Official Transcripts In order for transcripts to be considered official, they must be in a sealed envelope and bear an original seal/stamp and/or official signature from an appropriate signatory.  Official transcripts can be submitted as indicated below: - Sent via the Ontario Universities' Application Centre (OUAC), if eligible. - Mailed/couriered to Toronto Metropolitan University, SeviceHub, 350 Victoria Street, Toronto, ON Canada M5B 2K3 - Delivered in person to the ServiceHub, located at 380 Victoria Street, Podium Building (POD) Room 150. Please visit the Document Submission webpage for more detailed information on transcript requirements and instructions on submitting your transcripts.

prompt: How do I enroll in my undergraduate courses?
completion: Course Enrolment Full-time first-year students are automatically enroled into first semester Required courses, and are required to enrol in elective courses. Starting in August, you can view the courses you have been automatically enroled in on MyServiceHub, accessed via my.torontomu.ca . You can select the remaining elective courses, and enrol in or adjust your required course enrolments (if required) during your enrolment appointment or the open enrolment period. Part-time students, or students admitted late, are not automatically enroled into required courses, and must enrol in all of their courses for the first semester. Students can select and enrol in courses during their enrolment appointment or the open enrolment period. Program curriculum can be viewed in the Undergraduate Calendar.
